text: I feel like I'm constantly seeking dopamine hits or rewarding experiences.
I engage in behaviors (substances, activities, or habits) that I know are harmful but can't stop.
I feel like I'm a reward-chasing machine, constantly pursuing the next high or pleasure.
I need increasing amounts of a substance or activity to achieve the same effect (tolerance).
I experience withdrawal symptoms when I try to stop or reduce my addictive behavior.
I spend excessive amounts of time obtaining, using, or recovering from my addictive behavior.
I continue my addictive behavior despite knowing it causes problems in my life.
I give up important social, occupational, or recreational activities because of my addictive behavior.
I have strong cravings or urges to engage in my addictive behavior.
I feel like I can't function normally without my addictive substance or behavior.
I can enjoy activities and experiences without needing them to be intense or extreme.
I can stop engaging in behaviors when I recognize they're becoming problematic.
I maintain a healthy balance between work, leisure, and self-care activities.
I can experience pleasure and satisfaction without needing to constantly seek more intense experiences.
I have good impulse control and can resist urges to engage in harmful behaviors.
I feel like I'm addicted to the feeling of reward and constantly need more.
I engage in risky behaviors to get the same level of excitement or pleasure I used to get from normal activities.
I feel like my life revolves around obtaining and using my addictive substance or behavior.
I continue my addictive behavior even when it damages my relationships, health, or career.
I can maintain healthy habits and don't feel compelled to engage in addictive behaviors.
